items.title: South Korea: Impeached Yoon says pause in presidency 'temporary' | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
Less than two weeks after his short-lived martial law decree, South Korea's president has been impeached and suspended. Yoon Suk Yeol says he'll step aside, as the country's constitutional court now considers his future.

items.title: Diplomats meet in Jordan to discuss Syria's future | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
Diplomats from the European Union, United States and the Arab world are meeting in Jordan, as the international community attempts to help steer Syria's lightning revolution. US Secretary of State Anthony Blinken met with Turkish Foreign Minister Hakan Fidan during the talks. Blinken is on a Middle east tour hoping to establish a common front, as Syria works on setting up a new government after the regime of Bashar al-Assad collapsed last week. 

For more news go to: http://www.dw.com/en/

items.title: Georgians protest against new President | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
Pro-EU protesters took to the streets in Georgia on Saturday (14 Dec. 2024) as an electoral college dominated by the ruling party chose a new president known for his vehement anti-West views and opposition to LGBTQ rights. Former soccer star Mikheil Kavelashvili received 224 votes out of a possible 300 from the electoral college. He was the only candidate in the election, which the opposition boycotted and has said it will not not recognize, insisting that current President Salome Zourabichvili remain the legitimate head of state.

For more news go to: http://www.dw.com/en/

items.title: John Mahama wins presidency as Ghana seeks economic revival | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
Ghana is preparing to usher in a new government, after John Mahama's victory in last week's presidential election. The change comes at a crucial time - Ghana is experiencing its worst economic tension in years, despite maintaining its democratic stability. Expectations are high but Mahama promises he will bring Ghana the "reset" it needs.

items.title: Israel-Hamas ceasefire in sight? Diplomats report negotiation progress | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
Diplomats are reporting progress in negotiations on reaching a ceasefire between Israel and Hamas in Gaza. The US Secretary of State Anthony Blinken says Hamas is re-engaging in talks as the Biden administration pushes for a deal before Donald Trump returns to office next month.  

But there's no let-up in the hostilities - the latest Israeli airstrikes have killed at least 22 people across the Gaza strip, in an attack on a school and a separate strike on a market in central Gaza.

items.title: Stabilizing Syria: What to make of HTS promises? | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
US Secretary of State Anthony Blinken has been touring the Middle East hoping to establish a joint approach while Syria's new leaders put an administrative framework in place. The Islamist group HTS that toppled the regime of Bashar al-Assad has said its government will be law-based and inclusive. But many Western powers still classify it as a terrorist organization. 

Diplomats from the US, the European Union, and Arab countries have been meeting in Jordan, as the international community tries to help stabilize Syria. 

00:00 The US, EU, and Arab countries trying to help stabilize Syria in Jordan 
00:39 Daniel Serwer, John Hopkins School of Advanced International Studies

items.title: What's driving the housing crisis in African countries? | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
Kenya is facing a critical housing shortage with a deficit of nearly 2 million units. 
Earlier this year, the government passed a controversial levy, that forces employed Kenyans to contribute 1.5% of their income towards housing construction. It claims that this levy would finance the construction of 200,000 affordable houses annually. But how realistic is that? And will it be affordable enough for the thousands of homeless people on the margins of poverty? DW's Edith Kimani reports from Nairobi.
In South Africa, Cape Town is also facing a housing crisis. There are concerns that an influx of Western remote workers are worsening the situation by driving up property prices.
These 'digital nomads' earn in foreign currencies, giving them an edge over locals in the rental market. And South Africa's new three-year visa for remote workers could attract even more of them, adding to concerns about affordable housing. DW's Dianne Hawker has more.

For more news go to: http://www.dw.com/en/

For more news, analysis and background information on the German election 2025 go to our dedicated page: https://www.dw.com/en/german-election-2025/t-70794502

items.title: US officials in 'direct contact' with Syria's HTS rebels | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
US Secretary of State Antony Blinken says American officials have been in "direct contact" with Syrian rebel group Hayat Tahrir al-Sham. That despite HTS being on the US terrorism list.
Blinken has been in Jordan for talks with officials from several Arab countries and Turkey, as well as the EU and UN. They've agreed to support a peaceful transition process in Syria, and urged the country's new rebel leaders to protect citizens rights. The Islamist group HTS has promised to govern inclusively after toppling Bashar al-Assad's dictatorship a week ago. DW's Aya Ibrahim reports from Damascus.

For more news go to: http://www.dw.com/en/

items.title: What obstacles does S. Korea's Constitutional Court face in Yoon ruling? | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
South Korea's opposition has urged the Constitutional Court to quickly give its ruling on the future of President Yoon Suk Yeol.
On Saturday, South Korean lawmakers voted to impeach the president over his botched martial law attempt. He has been supended while the country's top court decides whether to remove him from office. Opposition leader Lee Jae-myung said in a press conference that a swift decision by the court will help alleviate the national turmoil.

00:00 South Korea's opposition calls for quick ruling on Yoon
00:34 DW speaks with Cho Hee-kyoung, professor of Law at Hongik University in Seoul

items.title: Georgia's president says she won't step down: What could happen | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
A bitter standoff over Georgia's next president has led to more protests, deepening the country's political crisis. On Saturday, Pro-EU demonstrators rallied outside parliament to protest the appointment of former soccer player Mikheil Kavelashvili, forcing authorities to postpone the switch on of Christmas lights. The incumbent president says she won't step down until new elections are held.

00:00 Georgia in crisis
00:24 DW's Grzegorz Szymanowski reports from Tbilisi
04:08 DW speaks with Tinatin Khidasheli in Tbilisi. She is chair of the Georgian think tank Civic IDEA and also served as Georgia's defense minister from 2015 to 2016. Her party The Republican Party of Georgia was in a coalition with the Georgian Dream.

For more news go to: http://www.dw.com/en/

items.title: 'The crisis is likely to deepen and the options begin to narrow' | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
In Georgia Mikheil Kavelashvili was elected as new president on Saturday as demonstrators gathered outside parliament to denounce the vote. The sitting president Salome Zurabishvili has declared the vote illegitimate and has refused to step down. She has called the electoral process unfair. The new president has been elected amid a constitutional crisis and after weeks of mass pro-EU protests. 

00:00 Protests in Georgia
00:25 Natalie Sabanadze, Former Georgian Ambassador to the EU
